Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
 How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
 Specific time frames for each violation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.

ALLEGATION:
The agency failed to inform a foster family of the reason for removal of three foster
children.
INVESTIGATION:
I interviewed the complainant, Complainant A by telephone on 1/10/2020.
Complainant A reported Child 1(age 5), Child 2((age 4), and Child 3 (age 3) are
siblings, who were removed from Foster Parent A and Foster Parent B’s foster home
on 12/9/2019. She reported the family had only a three-hour warning/notice of the
removal. Complainant A reported the children had resided with the foster parents
since they were ages one, seven-months and zero respectively. Additionally, that
prior to the removal, as late as a home visit in November 2019, the agency
supported the children’s placement with and adoption by Foster Parent A and Foster
Parent B. The agency completed Foster Parent A and Foster Parent B’s family
adoptive family assessment and was recommending them for adoption of the
children. Complainant A reported the emergency removal of the children was not
making sense. Complainant A wondered whether the removal was connected to
Foster Parent A’s inquiry in November 2019 pertaining to payments for
transportation and clothing’s which the foster parents had not received.
3

Complainant A reported it seems as if the agency just does not want Foster Parent A
and Foster Parent to adopt the children anymore. She indicated since the children’s
removal; the agency has been grappling at straws to show reasons for the removal.
The agency has reported that Child 2 was dehydrated and still in pull-ups and has
used that against Foster Parent A and Foster Parent B. Complainant A reported
Child 2 was dehydrated because he had stomach flu. Child 2 was in a pull-up
because she put the pull-up on Child 2 because he is four, he was going on a long
ride to a place he didn’t know, with people he didn’t know. She didn’t want him to
have an accident. She reported the family still does not know why the agency
removed the children.
Complainant A acknowledged there was a special evaluation initiated against Foster
Parent A and Foster Parent, which is pending. Complainant A reported knowing that
abuse or neglect has to be a reason for an emergency removal of children from a
foster home. Complainant A vehemently denied those issues being something that
were occurring by Foster Parent A and Foster Parent B.
I interviewed Foster Parent A by telephone on 1/17/2020. Foster Parent A affirmed
the information as reported by Complainant A. Foster Parent A said, she and Foster
Parent B have cared for the children for over four years; and they had been
approved to adopt them. The adoptions were targeted to be completed by May 2019,
but the date kept changing. A petition was filed but the court discovered their
fingerprints had expired, needed to be updated. The agency was to do that. Then in
November 2019, a complaint was made against them requiring an investigation.
Foster Parent A reported the agency also reported that two years ago there was an
allegation of medical neglect about them, which she didn’t know about. She
acknowledged that that allegation may, in part, be an aspect of the current special
evaluation. She reported taking Child 3 to the doctor for failure to thrive years back.
Now there is concern about her allegedly not taking the child to the emergency room
(ER) after the doctor’s office was unable to get the child admitted to the hospital. She
said the doctor therein told her to come back tomorrow and take the child to the ER,
which she did. The ER didn’t see what the big issue was. She said the doctor had
concerns with the size of Child 3’s head, thinking it was shrinking, but the doctor had
measured Child 3’s head incorrectly. Foster Parent A said she kept her foster care
worker aware of all of that over the two days that incident went on. She said the
agency is now alleging she also took the child off pedicure without the physician’s
consent and switched doctors. However, she only switched doctors so that all the
children, including her biological son, could be under the care of one doctor, rather
than multiple doctors, which was the case with that medical provider. She reported
not understanding this all being a complaint now.
Foster Parent A reported the children were removed on 12/9/2019 around 2:30pm.
She did not deny that the agency had contacted them by telephone prior to the
home visit. She reported, their licensing worker, Licensing Worker (LW)1, LW 2 who
was completing the special evaluation, along with and Foster Care Worker/
4

Supervisor (FCW/S) C were the staff from the agency. The staff/ agency never gave
them a reason for the removal. The staff only said it was in the children’s best
interest, but the agency told another state entity, they were concerned with the
children mental health. LW 1 said he didn’t’ support the removal.
Foster Parent A did not know whether the Michigan Children’s Institute (MCI)
superintendent had given an opinion related to the children’s removal. The agency
informed them the agency is not recommending them for adoption. The agency has
another family wishing to adopt the children and has “made the comment we’re too
busy to adopt”, which is not true. She and Foster Parent B still wish to adopt and
have an attorney pursuing adoption of the children.
Chief Administrator A, Foster Care/Adoption Program Manager (FC/APM) B,
Adoption Worker D, FCW/S C, and LW 1 were interviewed by me on-site on
1/23/2020. I interviewed Licensing Supervisor M and LW 2 by telephone on
2/4/2020. Each of these staff denied the allegation.
Each of the above-listed staff persons reported an emergency family team meeting
(FTM) was held by telephone on 12/9/2019 with Foster Parent A and Foster Parent
B. At that time both foster parents were informed of the plan to remove the children
and the reason for replacing the children.
Chief Administrator A and FC/APM B reported it was accurate that the agency had
approved the family for adoption and was moving forward with such until a complaint
allegation was made in July 2019. Then another in November 2019. They reported
after a February 2019 complaint/special evaluation on the family had previously
been resolved, MCI consent was requested. MCI consent was obtained for the
children’s adoption around May of 2019 and the agency was one day away from
petitioning the court for the adoptions when the July 2019 complaint was received,
alleging physical maltreatment. The MCI superintendent was informed of the matter
and advised a new MCI consent was required following the successful resolution of
the July 2019 complaint investigation. Sometime between the time of the July 2019
complaint and resolution of that special evaluation, the agency discovered one of the
foster parents’ fingerprints had expired. Thereafter, the November 2019 foster home
licensing complaint was received against Foster Parent A and Foster Parent B’s
foster home. The agency had ongoing consultations with the MCI superintendent,
inclusive of one on 12/9/2019, where the superintendent supported the removal of
Child 1, Child 2, and Child 3 from this foster home. Chief Administrator A and
FC/APM B reported the removal of the children was due to concerns for the
children’s ongoing, safety, care and supervision. That based on information, which
surfaced via the adoption worker’s work on the case, pertaining to the children’s
medical and emotional needs and the November 2019 special evaluation, removal
was assessed in the children’s best interest. The agency staff informed the foster
parents of the reason for the removal. A Foster Care Review Board (FCRB)hearing
occurred on the matter on 12/18/2019. The FCRB supported the agency’s action to
replace the children.
5

FCW/S C reported, and Adoption Worker D, Licensing Supervisor M and LW 2
affirmed that during the telephone call to Foster Parent A and Foster Parent B, on
12/9/2019, FCW/S C informed the foster parent the call was an emergency FTM to
discuss placement and licensing concerns. Each of these staff members reported
both foster parents were on speaker phone, and during the call agency staff took a
role in explaining concerns and the agency’s positions related to the placement, the
licensing investigation and adoption. FCW/S C reported she advised Foster Parent
A and Foster Parent B the agency would be replacing the children due to the
multiple special evaluations about discipline, the home; new concerns pertaining to
the foster parents not following up on the children’s needs, as were uncovered by
Adoption Worker D; and overall concerns for the children’s ongoing physical and
emotional safety. FCW/S C advised and arranged for the children’s replacement on
12/9/2019 at 2:30pm. FCW/S C reported when she, LW 1, and LW 2 arrived at the
foster home, the foster parents asked why the children were being removed, and if
there was anything, they could do to rectify the situation. Because other people
were at the home and emotions were high for the children and family, FCW/S C did
not go into the reasons again in detail. She told the foster parents the removal was
for reasons outlined to them on the telephone earlier that day. On 12/9/2019, FCW/S
C provided the foster parents with the Foster Parent Notification of Move(DHS-30)
form advising them of their right to appeal each respective child’s move and
denoting a reason for the move. FCW/S C reported she and LW 2 removed the
children from the foster home. LW 1 stayed behind to answer any questions Foster
Parent A and Foster Parent A might have. Since that time, neither foster parent has
tried to contact her to asked questions or request clarification.
Adoption Worker D reported she was assigned Child 1, Child 2 and Child 3’s
adoption case in October 2019. At that time the adoption was on hold due to a
special evaluation being underway pertaining to the foster home. Sometime during
that time, she discovered Foster Parent B’s fingerprints expired/were not processed.
The updated prints were needed before the agency could re-apply for MCI adoption
consent. Adoption Worker D sent the print for reprocessing on 11/12/2019. Then,
on 11/14/2019 while updating the foster family’s adult references for the updated
adoption home study, another complaint was received. The complaint alleged
Foster Parent A smacked Child 1. A special evaluation was therein initiated by the
licensing staff. Subsequently, Adoption Worker D’s review of the foster children’s
case records and subsequent medical records revealed concerning information
pertaining to Child 3’s failure to thrive, the child’s loss of weight issues, the foster
parents lack of follow through related to Child 3’s needs and the doctor’s
advisements. Information also came out surrounding Foster parent A’s supervision
and emotional bond or lack thereof with Child 1. Adoption Worker D reported these
matters were discussed with the foster parents during the 12/9/2019 telephone FTM
pertaining to the removal. At that time Foster Parent A kept stating “You are
removing the children?” “We said, yes.” for the reasons they outlined. Adoption
Worker D reported the removal of the children was not just that the agency was
concerned with the mental health of the children, nor were the foster parents told the
6

removal was because the foster parents were overwhelmed. Adoption Worker D
reported during the 12/9/2019 foster home visit, she again informed the family the
removal was for the prior specific reasons, inclusive of medical concerns and
supervision, discussed with them earlier that day.
Licensing Supervisor M reported she participated in the12/9/2019 emergency
telephone FTM with Foster Parent A and Foster Parent B, at which time she
informed them of the licensing staff preliminary findings related to the November
2019 initiated special evaluation. She indicated at this time the agency will be
recommending revocation of the foster home’s license.
LW 1 reported it was true he was initially not in favor of replacement of the children,
but after additional concerns and information emerged, he was. He affirmed his
presence with Adoption Worker D and LW 2 for the children’s removal from foster
parent home on 12/9/19. He reported at the request of the foster parents, he stayed
at the foster home after Adoption Worker D and LW 2 left with the children. The
foster parents wanted him to answer questions. They wanted to know the process
for appeal. This was his first removal and he couldn’t answer all their questions
about that. Additionally, Foster Parent B’s mother, father, and sister, as well the
foster parent’s son were present and he was concern about privacy, so he advised
the foster parents to call him. The foster parents heard what was explained by the
agency about the reasons for the replacement. They never reported any concerns of
not hearing what was being explained to them during the 12/9/2019 telephone call
nor referenced such during the home visit.
I reviewed the DHS-30 form for Child 1, Child 2 and Child 3. All three of the forms
listed the reason for removal as item number five: “MDHHS believes it is in the
child’s best interest to be moved. Foster Parent A and Foster Parent B signed the
form for each of the children on 12/9/2019.
Reviewed:
Case file records which showed:
 Child 1(DOB 5/5/2014), Child 2 (DOB 8/2/2015) were made MCI wards on
8/31/2018. They are wards of Wayne County.
 Child 3(DOB 9/8/2016) was made an MCI ward on 5/4/2018. She is a MCI
ward of Claire County.
 Foster Parent A and Foster Parent B have been licensed foster parents since
2015.
 A copy of a 12/23/2019 FCRB’s Appeal Investigation letter to the MCI
superintendent pertaining to a 12/18/2019 FCRB hearing. The document
denoted the FCRB supported the agency’s decision to move the children.
 Case documents as referenced earlier in this report.
A copy of a 12/6/2019 and 12/9/2019 email from Adoption Worker D to the MCI
Superintendent, GAL attorneys and others regarding the proposed removal and
decision to remove the children from the foster home.
7

APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.12405 Change of placement.
(3) The agency shall document all of the following in the
child's record before a change of placement occurs:
(i) That the current foster parent was notified in writing
of the following information:
(i) Not less than 14 calendar days in advance, of the
change, except when prior notification would jeopardize the
child's care or safety. If prior notice is not provided, then
the agency shall notify the foster parent, at the time of the
change, why prior notice was not given.
(ii) Of the current foster parent's rights concerning
the change in placement.
ANALYSIS: The evidence does not support the allegation or information as
reported by Complainant A and Foster Parent A. Foster Parent
A and Foster Parent B were provided with detail information as
to why Child 1, Child 2 and Child 3 were being removed from
their care during a telephone call on 12/9/2019. They were also
informed of their right to appeal via the DHS-30 Foster Parent
Notification of Move form on 12/9/2019.
Child 1, Child 2 and Child 3 are MCI wards and the MCI
superintendent was apprised of actions and concerns pertaining
to the children’s placement and care. The MCI superintendent
supported all three children’s replacements.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISHED
ALLEGATION:
Foster care placement change procedures did not occur.
INVESTIGATION:
Complainant A was interviewed by telephone on 1/10/2020. Complainant A reported
there was not an FTM related to Child 1, Child 2, and Child 2’s replacement.
Complainant A acknowledged Foster Parent A and Foster Parent B appealed the
agency’s removal of the children via the Foster Care Review Board (FCRB), but the
FCRB sided with the agency. Complainant A reported Child 1’s attorney didn’t know
about Child 1’s replacement until the day of my interview with Complainant A. Child
1’s and Child 2’s attorney sided with the agency related to their replacement.
Foster Parent A was interviewed by telephone on 1/17/2020. She affirmed the
complainant’s information related to the FCRB and the children’s attorney
information. She reported the FCRB reported they sided with the agency because
she hit one of the children, which she reported was accidental. Additionally, that
8

there were concerns, as reported earlier pertaining the other aspect of the special
evaluation.
Foster Parent A did not report that there was or was not an FTM about Child 1, Child
2 and Child 3’s removal.
FCW/S C reported, and Adoption Worker D, Licensing Supervisor M, LW 1 and LW
2 affirmed that an emergency FTM to discuss placement and licensing concerns was
held with Foster Parent A and Foster Parent B on 12/9/2019 as previously report.
During a home visit on 12/9/2019, FCW/S C provided the foster parents with the
DHS-30-Foster Parent Notification of Move form.
FCW/S C reported she completed the Family Team Meeting Report (DHS-1105) and
the Foster Care/Juvenile Action Summary(DHS-69) for each child. She indicated the
required documents were completed timely and updated to MISACWIS at a later
date. She reported the DHS-69 was provided to the respective child’s GAL attorney
via email on 2/7/2020. The DHS-69 was not sent to the DHHS referring worker
because it was uploaded in MISACWIS. She indicated the court was not notified of
the children’s replacement on 12/11/2019 as documented on the form. That was an
error. She stated a copy of the DHS-69 notifying Child 1 and Child 2’s court of
jurisdiction of their placement changed occurred via email on 2/7/2020. Child 3’s
court of jurisdiction notification occurred via a court report on 12/20/2019.
Adoption Worker D reported on 11/18/2019 the MCI superintendent contacted the
agency regarding the status of the children’s adoption and about concerns related to
Foster Parent A and Parent B’s new and past special evaluations related to
discipline. A case conference was held with the MCI superintendent in November
2019. Adoption Worker D reported she invited the children’s Department of Health
and Human Services (DHHS) Workers and supervisors, Guardian ad litem (GAL)
attorneys, MCI staff persons and the agency staff to a telephone case conference
via email on 11/18/2019. The case conference was set for and held on 11/19/2019
with all, except the GAL attorneys, participating in the telephone case conference.
The GAL attorneys could not attend. On that same date, Adoption Worker D
provided all invitees, the Permanency Resource Manager (PRM) and the other
stated individuals a written summary of the telephone case conference discussion,
concerns and the recommendations made. The agency was to complete the foster
parents’ special evaluation and to keep the “team members” informed.
Adoption Worker D reported during the special evaluation further information was
revealed regarding Foster Parent A and Foster Parent B and their care of the
children as referenced earlier in this report. On 12/6/2019 Adoption Worker D
emailed the team members noted above of the agency’s preliminary decision to
remove the children from the home, as well as, the agency’s anticipated decision of
not recommending the foster family for adoption. Another email was sent
requesting/scheduling a case conference for 12/9/2019. On 12/9/2019 the agency
staff members, the MCI superintendent, PRM Worker and DHHS Worker for Child 3
attended the telephone case conference. The GAL for Child 3 reported she could not
9

attend, neither of the children’s GAL attorneys participated. At the telephone
conference the case was discussed along with the agency’s rationale for removal.
The MCI superintendent and team members in attendance at the telephone
conference agreed with the recommendation and that all three children be removed
immediately. Adoption Worker D emailed the conference attendees and all other
previously reported “team members” the plan and outcome of the conference.
Adoption Worker D reported Child 3’s GAL subsequently indicated he did not
support this child’s removal and that he felt he didn’t have opportunity to participate
in the case conference. She indicated Clair County Court has since asked DHHS to
investigate the agency on this matter.
I reviewed MISACWIS and social work contact documentations pertaining to the
stated allegation with respect to Family Teaming Meetings and MISACWIS entry:
 A social work case note documented a telephone FTM on 12/9/2019; and a
Family Team Meeting Reports (DHS-1105) for the children all denoted an
unplanned FTM on 12/9/2019. The DHS-1105 denoted the agency staff in
attendance in person, and that Foster Parent A, Foster Parent B and LW 2
were present via telephone.
APPLICABLE RULE
Policy FOM Family Team Meeting.
722-06 B
FTMs must occur within the required time frames as outlined in
the following tables:
If the caseworker and supervisor determine that it is in the
child's best interest to change placements:
 An FTM must be held at least three business days prior
to a best interest placement change to allow interested
parties the opportunity to participate in the decision; see
Family Team Meeting in this item and FOM 722-06B,
Family Team Meeting. The supervisor must approve the
move before a change of placement is made.
 If the child is an MCI/state ward and the current caregiver
expresses either a verbal or written interest in adopting
the child, the MCI superintendent must be consulted prior
to the placement change.
 The caregiver has the option of appealing the decision to
the Foster Care Review Board (FCRB); see Caregiver
Appeal to the Foster Care Review Board in this item.
ANALYSIS: The evidence showed the intent of this policy was met.
10

Child 1’s, Child 2’s, and Child 3’s DHHS worker, DHHS
supervisor, GAL attorney and the MCI superintendent were
apprised of a plan to discuss removal of the children from the
foster home via an 12/6/2019 email. That email also requested a
12/9/2019 case conference. Child 1 and Child 2’s GAL attorney
reported they would be available for the conference. Child 3’s
GAL attorney indicated she was not available.
The agency staff conducted a 12/9/2019 telephone conference
with the DHHS staff members, and the MCI superintendent. Per
Adoption Worker D the GAL attorneys did not attend that
telephone conference. The GAL attorneys and all the indicated
individuals, who had been invited and or attended the 12/9/2019
telephone conference, were provided an email summary of the
outcome of the 12/9/2019 telephone conference; inclusive of the
decision to remove the children immediately, on 12/9/2019.
The agency conducted an emergency FTM with the foster
parents and agency staff on 12/9/2019, prior to the children’s
move from Foster Parent A and Foster Parent B’s foster home
on that same date.
A Foster Parent Notification of Move (DHS-30) form for Child 1,
Child 2 and Child 3 advising the foster parents of their right to
appeal the respective child’s move was completed by the
agency, signed by the foster parents. A copy of the DHS-30 was
given the foster parents for each child on 12/9/2019.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISHED
ALLEGATION:
Documents were not uploaded into MISACWIS as required.
INVESTIGATION:
In addition to the interviewee’s previous statements as previously reported about the
placement change, I reviewed MISACWIS and the following case record
documentations pertaining the stated allegation with respect to Family teaming
meetings and MISACWIS entry:
 MISAWIS record showed social work contact entries for face-to-face contacts
with the foster parents/ others, related to the special evaluation visit on
11/22/2019; the foster home visit with the foster parents and foster children
11

on 12/9/2019, and worker/ supervisor contact on 12/12/2019 showed the
MISACWIS entries did not occur until 12/12/2019 for the 11/22/2019 contact,
and 1/14/2020 for the 12/9/2019 and 12/12/2019 contact.
 MISACWIS did not show a social work case contact for 2/4/2020 showing the
DHS-1105 was sent to Foster Parent A and Foster Parent B, as reported by
FCW/S C.
 MISACWIS did not show a social work case contact for 2/7/2020 showing the
DHS-69 was sent to the court or to the GAL attorneys as reported by FCW/S
C.
 MISACWIS records did not show documentation that all team members were
provided a copy of the DHS-1105 form.
APPLICABLE RULE
Policy FOM Family Team Meeting.
722-06B
Post FTM
Following the FTM, the caseworker is responsible for the
following:
 Providing the DHS-1105, Family Team Meeting Report,
to all participants (in person and by phone), legal parents,
and casework supervisor. These documents must also be
uploaded into MISACWIS.
 The caseworker must enter the FTM information in
MISACWIS using the FTM hyperlink within seven
business days of the FTM.
ANALYSIS: The Family Team Meeting Report (DHS-1105 ) was
documented timely per its 12/11/2019 completion. However, the
agency was not compliance with all aspect of this policy:
 The FTM information was not entered/uploaded in
MISACWIS until 1/23/2020, more than the seven
business days of the FTM date as required by this policy.
 MISACWIS did not show documentation that the DHS-
1105 was provided the foster parents on or before the
2/4/2020 date FCW/S C reported it was provided.
 MISACWIS records did not show documentation that all
other participants were provided a copy of the DHS-1105.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
APPLICABLE RULE
Policy FOM Case Contacts.
722-06H
Timely Entry of Case Contacts
The caseworker must enter the required face-to-face contacts
listed below in MISACWIS within five business days of the
12

contact. This includes attempted and missed face-to-face
contacts.
Any face-to-face contact with children, parents, or caregivers
made by any of the following:
 Foster care caseworker/supervisor.
 CPS caseworker/supervisor.
 Adoption caseworker/supervisor.
 Permanency resource monitors.
 Education planners.
 Michigan Youth Opportunities Initiative coordinators
ANALYSIS: Face-to face contacts with the foster parents’ for a special
evaluation home visit on 11/22/2019; Child 1, Child 2, and Child
3’ replacement visit on 12/9/2019; and a worker/ supervisor
supervision on 12/12/2019 were not entered with five business
days as required by the policy.
Additionally, a social work contact of the following was not
documented in MISACWIS:
 An email or letter of the DHS-1105 being sent to the
foster parents on 2/4/2020.
 A letter, email or other documentation of a 12/20/2019
notification to Child 3’s court of jurisdiction, informing the
court of Child 3’s replacement.

ALLEGATION:

inform them they could have a support person present prior to being interviewed.
INVESTIGATION:
I interviewed Foster Parent A via telephone on 1/17/2020. She reported the agency
informed them in November 2019 that a complaint was made against them. When
the agency came out to their home, the agency never told them what the complaint
was. When the agency workers were at their home, her in-laws were there, and the
agency workers would not talk in front of the in-laws. Foster Parent A was not sure
whether the agency informed her and Foster Parent B they could have a support
present with them when interviewed. However, Foster Parent A stated she knew
they could.
Licensing Supervisor M and LW 2 were interviewed, separately by me, via telephone
on 2/3/2020. Both denied the allegations. They reported the foster parents were
informed of the allegations and their right to have a support person. The foster
parents declined to have a support person.
Licensing Supervisor M reported she was not on the call when LW 2 spoke with
Parent A and Foster Parent B about receipt of the November 2019 complaint.

received alleging foster home rule violations and to give the foster parents the
details of the complaint at the home visit. She reported that’s what LW 2 did.
Licensing Supervisor M reported those former instructions were advised so as to
safeguard against the foster parents trying to coach or prepare the children prior to
the worker interviewing them. Licensing Supervisor M mailed a 11/18/2019 letter

LW 2 wrote to the foster parents. The letter outlined there was a complaint and the
possible rule violations. The foster parents received that letter prior to LW 2s’
11/22/2019 home visit. LW 2 reported seeing that letter on the foster family’s table.

no other outside person was present at the foster home visit; and LW 2 conducted
interviews.
Licensing Supervisor M informed the foster parents of the agency’s preliminary
licensing recommendation during the emergency FTM call with Foster Parent A and
